19117: Flowstone Charger.author: blurrymadness

Indeed, could combo well with meekstone, the red creatures who allow those with power 2 or less to be unblockable, etc..

Comboing => 5 unblockable power. I'd say that's reasonable. People forget that sometimes goofy rules interactions are the appropriate way to use a card. Yeah, the card in a vacuum is super-weak state wise, but out of the vacuum with the other 12 or 13000 cards in the game, could be quite usable (or even good.)

Also, the art is awesome.

19135: Vindicate.author: Hovercraft
19135: Vindicate.text_parsed: No one seems to have pointed out that this can destroy basic lands. Being able to splash this into a black deck with Scrublands and blow up cards like Moat is obviously amazing. but then to be able to redundantly annihilate your opponent's lands is the icing on the cake. You play first you maybe Duress someone then your opponent grumbles plays a land passes their turn and you Sinkhole them. Then they play another land and they pass and for the heck of it you Vindicate their next only land. You now have 4 lands they have 0. This is obviously very silly. Black cannot actually destroy enchantments. Nor can it do much about Artifacts.

19135: Vindicate.author: yyukichigai
19135: Vindicate.text_parsed:
Why is it that the most simple cards often have the most expensive prices on the secondary market?

Great card. Very timely, and in the environment it was printed it a little more difficult to use than it is now. Very few people played B/W competitively back in the day. Of course, I'd argue that printing this card was one of the contributing factors towards the (continuing) rise of splashing, so maybe it wasn't all that well thought out.

Still, can't argue with results. This card does one thing and does it well. Probably the best permanent removal spell out there. 5/5.

19135: Vindicate.author: Sharu
19135: Vindicate.text_parsed:
I have a problem.
I can't decide what my favourite thing about this card is.
The effect- best removal ever.
The art- agonising demise of the fearful Yawgmoth.
The flavour- the culmination of the legacy, the final defeat of the multiverse's greatest villian (not you, Bolas).
The flavour text- Gerrard at his most awesome ever.
Or the simplicity- "Destroy target permanent." That's it.

This card is actually beautiful.
As near as perfection can be, to me at least.
Versatility, power, flavour, amazing.

5/5, and I wish I could give it more.

aside from the promo foil and a possible From the Vault/Premium Deck version.

so if you want these, I would buy them now, before they get even pricier.

I wouldn't be surprised if Maelstrom Pulse follows a similar lifespan,
and as such, I'm snapping some up now before they cost $30, as well.

19135: Vindicate.author: blurrymadness
19135: Vindicate.text_parsed:
The thing about a card like this is it's a no-brainer.
-It's never dead.
-It plugs the holes in whatever you're missing. You have enchant removal? Who cares, this hits all that other stuff! You have creature removal? Never fear, have some more and btw kill anything else that bothers you!
-The color combination is powerful to begin with.

Some may argue every color combo has had it's heyday, but I'd argue:
-W/B hits everything (Hand, every permanent type, graveyard)
-has every kind of Kill spell (wipes, sacrifice, targetted up the yin-yang)
-has recursion
-has all of this on EtB effects (making it quite relevant against Show and Tell)

This card is the epitome of the color combination; it is to W/B as Maelstrom Pulse is to G/B

Without any other color, it can counter every strategy without thinking hard at all; which, IMO, makes it *the* color combination. G/B can do most of that and I think time has proven that combination is about on par. Without relying on counterspells, that's about as good as you can get for coverage.

19135: Vindicate.author: FlashCaster
19135: Vindicate.text_parsed:
Someone could say this was the coolest card ever and honestly I don't think I would try and argue with them.

There are quite a few targeted removals better than this in the tournament sense to include Swords to Plowshares, Terminate, Mortify, and Putrefy, but none of them are even close to as cool as this card.

The only card like this that I might think could be cooler would be one that read "Exile Target Permanent" but such a card just doesn't exist (yet). Even if they did print that card it would need to have an epic name, sick art, and cool flavor text to compete with this bad boy in that way.

Someone else here said "Vindicate is and will always be the best removal spell ever printed" but in the tournament sense this just isn't true, I am sorry. The best targeted removal from a tournament playability standpoint is easily Swords to Plowshares, which is why you see it played in tons of big events at the top 8 level and Vindicate not really at all.

As easy a 5/5 as they come, and quite possibly my favorite card ever.

19135: Vindicate.author: dakkon_moxerson
19135: Vindicate.text_parsed:
I've played Magic since it's inception and this card is amazing. I typically favor 'generic' removal spells in my decks, such as disenchant, removal spells with optional targets, because they are the best kind, imo. Swords to Plowshares being one of the few exceptions. For the simple reason that if you never use a card you draw, that is a waste of a draw and very likely a complete turn, whereas a card that can target multiple types has the best chance to have a valid target and the best chance to be playable. Vindicate has a valid target virtually 100% of the time. The sorcery speed of it is a drawback, but more than made up for by it's versatility. Any deck than can, should play 4 vidicates, with a sideboard of 2 swords and 2 disenchant.

As good a card as you can get.

25816: Overgrown Estate.author: majinara
25816: Overgrown Estate.text_parsed:
It's an ok multiplayer card. I have it in a multiplayer deck with Herald of Leshrac, so I can sac the lands before I have to give them back. Also, multiplayer games tend to be often rather slow and last long, meaning you can easily have 10 or more lands in play in the late game, which means that you have plenty of time to take that player with you, who tries to kill you.
No tournament card, but playable in the right decks.

25816: Overgrown Estate.author: stygimoloch
25816: Overgrown Estate.text_parsed: This has seen its fair share of tournament play. While on the surface not as good as Zuran Orb, it was actually better at the time of print, for powering up Necra Sanctuary. The late-game trade off of land for life isn't really the point of the card; it's really a surprisingly versatile Johnny card wrapped in the brown envelope of subpar utility.

25816: Overgrown Estate.author: Mode
25816: Overgrown Estate.text_parsed:
In general when compared to Zuran Orb this card is indeed rather second choice.

The effect is by 50% more effective, yet the mana cost claims a lot more effort.
When running deck with Herald of Leshrac, i'd seriously prefer the Orb for example since you can run a mono-colored deck then.

Of course when facing mono-red or mono-black decks, your opponents have a harder time to get rid of an enchantment rather than an artifact, and when you can use the casting cost for your advantage by playing Sanctuary enchantments, Bloom Tender or Bloodhall Ooze, this card will get also more appealing and preferable to the Orb.
But those are generic advantages every card of that type and/or colors has. I'd prefer Sterling Grove for example in an enchantment-based deck with Necra Sanctuary.

A triple-colored card is rather a mess to cast, this effort does in my opionion not get rewarded enough by this card. It should be able to provide more than only the current effect it has.
I guess it turned out that way since Wizards planned on creating an altered version of Dark Heart of the Wood.
Copmare this card to Doran, the Siege Tower for example. You get effectively a 5/5 body with a rather advantageous effect for your deck, or when arguing that this is also for being legendary, take a look at Woolly Thoctar, a triple-colored plain 5/4 body.

25825: Martyrs' Tomb.author: Aremath
25825: Martyrs' Tomb.text_parsed:
While generally it's awful, I've seen it in combination with Horobi, Death's Wail. At that point, it's "Pay 2 life: destroy target creature" which is okay in my book. Still...

Mostly, the reason is this:
Your creatures take damage primarily during combat, either because they block or are blocked. The only reason you block (in general) is to prevent damage to yourself. When you use martyrs' tomb to save your blocker, you're generally going to take 4-6 damage anyways, meaning that the block that you made did almost nothing for you.
It seems okay on the attack until you realize that your opponent can simply race you if you continue to use the ability to save your guys. Additionally, if he plays a high power, high toughness dude, you can no longer use the tomb to force your guys through.

If it cost {W} or {B}, it might be playable simply because the ability is sometimes relevant. at 4CMC, though, it's pretty bad.

And @Enchantment_Removal: 4 of the 6 {W}{B} Apocalypse cards are rated above 4.2, the other (besides this) is around a 3. This is really the only card that suffered because of vindicate...

25832: Temporal Spring.author: Paladin85
25832: Temporal Spring.text_parsed:
Instant? Are you people insane? This is an upgraded version of Boomerang losing the instant but putting it as your opponent's draw on his next turn. With green in the casting cost, potential 2nd turn spell if you let out a Llanowar Elves on turn 1 with a forest and put down an island on turn 2.

People forget that at times, Memory Lapse can be better than Counterspell. This is comparable to Boomerang

This slows any deck down played early, and can set opponents back late game by forcing them to recast and redraw their potential game winners

4.5/5 for the powerful effect early and late game

25833: Death Mutation.author: patronofthesound
25833: Death Mutation.text_parsed: This is an unusual ability (convert an enemy cmc into a saps) so I'm guessing the cost reflects their ineptitude at pricing at this time. Logically, if we consider the casual playable aether mutation as an unsummon stapled to 3g--gain 1/1 saps = to targets cmc, death mutation is a dark banishing stapled to the same for 6bg, costing one more than it should. I think the expense of this card is tied to its multiplicity and potential for great field advantage. Were it printed in modern times i think it would cost 5-6 but with a life loss drawback or the like. Sick card though, great flavor. I love cards that interact with the game on an imaginative level. This isn't just a few simple effects, its a concept card (ha!) that gives the game depth and poetry beyond the rules.

25859: Planar Despair.author: Keino
25859: Planar Despair.text_parsed: To whom it may concern: Yawgmoth didn't have a single form, he could take the shape of any of his minions. During "Apocalypse," he took the form of Hanna while Gerrard and Urza fought in Phyrexia. Yawgmoth was hiding as Hanna, but the Phyrexian Arena spoke and cheered in a singular, hissing voice. The good: I love the art, and regeneration without having to keep mana open is great.
The bad: volvers are better the bigger they are. So you can play them early on if necessary, but try to keep them as huge fatties for the late game. This dude can't be a huge fatty, so he falls a bit short in that matter.

Still: nice art. :) I had him as a 1-of in a deck about reckless assault and dega sanctuary.

25947: Degavolver.author: cats_and_me
25947: Degavolver.text_parsed: Regeneration has become stronger lately, and "free" regeneration allows you to play it together with mana-heavy mass-destroy spells! :) It's nice that you have four different options, but I don't like how one of them (1/1 creature for ~two~ mana) is something that you always never want, and how one of them (4/4 creature with first strike ~and~ regeneration) comes with anti-synergy between the abilities.. Also, I don't like how the red kicker creates a white ability: What's the purpose of working together with your enemies, the very interesting concept of this block, if you get something that you already have yourself?

25948: Cetavolver.author: achilleselbow
25948: Cetavolver.text_parsed:
Degavolver is worse. Trample and first strike are two of the most useful abilities, and since you're playing green he should be easy to pump.
These would be a lot better if they had been printed now, especially since the main ability associated with each color has changed, as we saw with the Lorwyn demigod auras. Black would probably get Fear/Intimidate instead of that awful 3-life regeneration, red might get Haste or even Double Strike instead of First Strike, and blue would either keep flying or get shroud instead. Trample alone is a little weak for green, so maybe it would get an extra +1/+1 as well.

25949: Necravolver.author: Kryptnyt
25949: Necravolver.text_parsed:
@Paladin85
Lifelink creatures still gain you life when they deal noncombat damage. The real difference between the two is that Lifelink happens without a chance to respond, and this version happens as a trigger on the stack that can be responded to. It can therefore stack with the same ability twice on a creature (two Spirit Links on one creature)
25949: Necravolver.text_posted:
@Paladin85

It can therefore stack with the same ability twice on a creature (two [autocard]Spirit Link[/autocard]s on one creature)

25951: Anavolver.author: brunsbr103
25951: Anavolver.text_parsed:
in my experience, the volver cycle is kind of hard to use. It poses so many questions of "when do I play this?", and eventually "would I rather play this or a different creature with similar abilities?"

now, hard to use doesn't necessarily mean bad
You need to ana1yze it almost as if it's four different cards
1. 3/3 for 3G
2. 4/4 with regenerate ability for 3GB
3. 5/5 with flying for 4GU
4. 6/6 with flying AND regenerate for 4GUB

the great thing about the volvers is that they come with options (duh), but if you need a green/black regenerating guy, might I suggest Spiritmonger. And if you need a 5/5 flier and you're running blue, go for sphinx of jwar isle.

I honestly can't think of a substitute for a 6/6 flying and regenerating creature, and I think that this is one of the better points of a volver. They're hardly worth it if they aren't kicked, but the more mana you kick them with the more unique they get. If you want to be able to chose between three different, and respectable, threats (and potentially a 3/3 for 4 mana as a last ditch resort), or you don't exactly know what you want, then the volvers are for you.

that is, if you have the mana. I wouldn't even consider them at all if I was only running two of the three colors

25951: Anavolver.author: achilleselbow
25951: Anavolver.text_parsed:
A 6/6 flyer for 7 mana is a pretty good deal, but not great, and the regenerating ability is kind of useless. 3 life is a pretty substantial amount, there aren't a lot of things that are going to kill a 6/6 with damage, and most removal spells bypass regeneration. The 5/5 flyer for 6 that you get if you just pay the blue kicker is also pretty good. Rakavolver is far superior though.

As for the awkward color costs, you can run this and Necravolver in a green/black or a green/blue deck as long as you just have a couple of Fertile Grounds.

25953: Pernicious Deed.author: Werewolf-
25953: Pernicious Deed.text_parsed:
@AvatarOfHOE

There's a reason Nevinyrral's Disk costs $10 a card and Pernicious Deed costs $25 a card. The Disk can be better in certain scenarios, yes, but in most decks where you can access the , Pernicious Deed is better. The great thing about the Deed is that you can CHOOSE what you want to destroy. If the thing that's winning you the game has 4cmc, you can use the deed to only hit everything ≤3cmc. And unlike other CMC sweepers like Powder Keg/Ratchet Bomb, this hits "cmc X or less," not "cmc equal to X." And of course this, unlike all those others (Disk included), can be activated the turn it hits the field.

25953: Pernicious Deed.author: blurrymadness
25953: Pernicious Deed.text_parsed:
Not only is it *that much better* than Gaze of Granite for obvious reasons, it has subtle reasons that it's better:

-It's {B} less color intensive, which is helpful
-It doesn't have {X} in it's cost, meaning that it's harder to counter-spell (due to you leaving mana open or casting it earlier). White also occasionally gets hard counters to {X} spells (not counterspells, but you get what I mean, like Medic)
-It's allowed to be activated at instant speed, meaning you can wait to pour in the same mana you would've anyway in order to kill an extra permanent, or to be ready to kill a crucial creature with another kill spell before igniting it the next turn.
-A pro *and* a con is that it misses planeswalkers. This sets it up perfectly for Garruk Wildspeaker to ramp it up a ton while protecting you with beasts. Also, Liliana of the Veil may see use in a deck with this included, and her low/common cost means that you don't want to nuke her with it.

and I'm sure there are other subtle advantages, such as putting it onto the field with replenish. The only times I can think of where Gaze is better is against Krosan Grip (if they left mana open) or odd situations where the casting cost matters (Manaplasm, Spellstutter, Chalice of the Void, etc..)

Oddly enough, it can save you as a T3 play to force an opponent to use part of T4 destroying it if you're desperate.

25953: Pernicious Deed.author: MechaKraken
25953: Pernicious Deed.text_parsed:
This card saved me during a Commander match. The guy was playing slivers with Sliver Overlord as his general. I was playing multi-colored with Cromat as mine.

He had me down to 15 life and 14 general damage. He also had Crystalline Sliver, Gemhide Sliver, and Heart Sliver out. He thought he had won the game because I had no board wipes in hand (he checked with Thoughtseize) and only a 1/1 white soldier token on the board.

I used Wargate to search for this, then played it with 2 mana pumped into it. It was enough to destroy his Crystalline Sliver, which made his creatures now targetable. On his turn, he put in Crypt Sliver, thinking that I only bought myself a turn, and I blocked the overlord with my soldier token.

On my turn, I top decked Nicol Bolas, Planeswalker and immediately played it to steal the overlord from him. From there, he couldn't touch me because I kept using the overlord to gain control of his slivers. He conceded after 2 turns. So yeah, this card saved me and provided for a humiliating defeat for my friend, lol.

Great card. Unless your opponent has far more life or creatures than you, it wins you the game by itself, since your opponent won't have the mana to get rid of this threat (except the moment it's trigger is on the stack before it resolved, so better play it when your opponent is tapped out or has no cards on hand).

If you want an easy combo, play ghostly prison and then this guy. That way your opponent cant attack you anymore at all for a few turns.

4.5 Stars easily

26259: Desolation Angel.author: zk3
26259: Desolation Angel.text_parsed:
What an interesting and elegant one-card combo.

Back in Arabian Nights, the Erhnamgeddon deck (Erhnam Djinn and Armageddon) revolved around the strategy of playing a big creature on turn 4 to get ahead on the board, then clear your opponent's resources on turn 5 so you STAY ahead.

Desolation angel plays both the role of Erhnam and geddon, as its 5/4 flying body gets you ahead on the board, and its ability ensures you stay ahead. Its power and evasion is a very efficient racer, too. My argument here is that you don't need Wrath effects with her stats.

The obvious comparison to this card is Desolation Giant, but the two sides of that card are a lot more redundant by only making sure you are +1 creatures to your opponent, but even a 3/3 gets outclassed in 4-5 turns before the damage becomes a significant guaranteed clock.
Angel can outrace many creatures, and a B/W deck back in apocalypse/7th edition had the best removal (Vindicate, Terror, pacifism) so keeping the threats low early on was relatively simple.

Unfortunately, the main downfall to this card was its colors, and the only "dual land" back then was Caves of Koilos, and neither of these colors had card draw/mana fixing to find more lands.
Great card in concept, and I feel it would still make a huge impact on today's game if it was reprinted.

26373: Quicksilver Dagger.author: adrian.malacoda
26373: Quicksilver Dagger.text_parsed:
@sygilber: Well, you could play this on an opponent's creature, but it doesn't benefit you. Spirit link has an ability that gives "you" life, whereas Quicksilver Dagger grants the creature an ability that states that "you" draw a card. On Spirit Link, the you refers to the controller of Spirit Link, since the ability is on Spirit Link and not the creature. Here, since the ability is being granted to the creature, only that creature's controller can activate it and when they do, they draw a card.

The only auras that have their own tap abilities (that don't say "Enchanted creature has...") are in Future Sight (see Flowstone Embrace), and those presumably haven't been expanded on because it is potentially confusing. The aura that you are looking for, that you can use to tap opponent's creatures, is Second Wind from that set.
26373: Quicksilver Dagger.text_posted:
@sygilber: Well, you could play this on an opponent's creature, but it doesn't benefit you. Spirit link has an ability that gives "you" life, whereas Quicksilver Dagger grants the creature an ability that states that "you" draw a card. On Spirit Link, the you refers to the controller of Spirit Link, since the ability is on Spirit Link and not the creature. Here, since the ability is being granted to the creature, only that creature's controller can activate it and when they do, they draw a card.

The only auras that have their own tap abilities (that don't say "Enchanted creature has...") are in Future Sight (see [autocard]Flowstone Embrace[/autocard]), and those presumably haven't been expanded on because it is potentially confusing. The aura that you are looking for, that you can use to tap opponent's creatures, is [autocard]Second Wind[/autocard] from that set.

26421: Mystic Snake.author: majinara
26421: Mystic Snake.text_parsed:
I think that some people don't quite understand the card. The 2/2 body by itself is not what matters. What matters is that it's a creature at all. Which means it can be easily reanimated, bounced to hand and replayed, flickered in and out of play and so on. Or, to put it into other words: it's not only a hard counter. It can not only kill players, creatures, planeswalkers and protect you. It can also lock down an opponent easily with lots of combos. And it is pure card advantage. Combine all that with a very powerful color combination and give it a fine mana cost, and you have an awesome card.

So if you complain about it only beeing 2/2, then you didn't understand it. :) And you never played against an opponent who really used this card.

26424: Legacy Weapon.author: DarthParallax
26424: Legacy Weapon.text_parsed:
Cheesesack's comment is more liked than Volcre's?
>.> Gatherer voters are inconsistent.

Anyway, I disagree with them both. I think the two arts should not be judged next to each other, I like them both. I think the arts serve two very different purposes. One shows the battle scene, one commemorates this historic moment in Magic by showing off lots of references to past Magic ala Time Spiral-like nostalgia.

To be more clear, THIS is the one I want in my deck, that I cast and say "Exile Target Thing" in a low ominous voice; and Xth Edition is the one I want in my binder. To be even more clear, Not my trade binder- my 'show off the cool stuff I've collected' Binder, where I keep FTV cards, Graveborn's foil Entomb, and things like that. The original versions go in decks, to me anyway. The later prints nearly always have art that tends have the same issues as Legacy Weapon- the cards even look like they belong under a glass case, not in the middle of a battlefield.

Exiled's Berserk is an amazing exception.

26424: Legacy Weapon.author: Bobth
26424: Legacy Weapon.text_parsed:
This picture only depicts part of the Legacy. It shows when the Weatherlight crashed into the Null Moon, pouring its White mana down onto Yawgmoth, which weakened him. Then Gerrard Capashen placed Urza's Mightstone and Weakstone into Karn, Silver Golem which made another laser beam and finished the job. Squee's Toy and various other artifacts were also involved somehow, I don't really get it. Maybe they were on the Weatherlight when it hit the moon?

The picture from 10E depicts everything, so they probably just couldn't fit it.

Based on that, this card should probably do something like Sudden Spoiling, then exile target creature. Also should not be repeatable - you can't break a moon open and drain its energies more than once. Oh well.

26447: Illuminate.author: majinara
26447: Illuminate.text_parsed:
It's a good card for very slow formats, such as Commander/EDH. Most newer players see only the high kicker cost, and dismiss the card immediately. But it's better than that.

First, the kicker cost is optional. When you just want to kill a creature, it's exactly as efficient as any other red X spell, requiring only one colored mana in addition to the X value. At the same time, the card gets much more efficient in the late game, where every single mana spent for X translates into one damage to a creature, one card drawn, and one damage to a player.

For example, play a 13 mana illuminate with all kickers in a late Commander game. X is then 5. A five damage blaze to a creature would cost normally six mana. A five damage blaze to a player would also cost six. A five card brain geyser would cost seven mana. That would cost together 19 mana, instead of 13. In addition, you'd have to spend three cards for these effects, instead of one, so to come out with the same card advantage, you'd have to cast a 9 mana braingeyser, ending up with a total cost of 21 mana, instead of 13. AND the mana cost would require four colored mana, instead of three on illuminate. AND it would take up three card slots in your deck, instead of one.

26451: Ice Cave.author: Palochka
26451: Ice Cave.text_parsed:
Braid of Fire's Card of the Day #16

If anyone reflects a spells mana, it can be countered since we're all in this ice cave together? Is that what this is supposed to represent?

Flavor aside, this is one of the most interesting Magic cards in print.

The entire dynamic of the game is turned upside down. It affects every player immediately. Visceral emotions are called upon when this piece of cardboard lands on the table. Players cannot believe that this exist.

Ice Cave is the king of multiplayer games. When it is cast, the room gets as cold as the cave our planeswalker personas are now dueling in. Open mana from any player sharing a color is a threat, no matter the cards in their hand. The best thing about this card is that it does not create a subgame that feels separate from Magic, as other cards can do. It merely serves to emphasize a specific element of the game that calls for careful plays, and, unfortunately, a lot of stalemates. Are you going to bait out your opponent's mana? Is that artifact in your hand even worth having right now?

So much fun.

"The flavor is both non-existent and hilarious." --Opined_Fluke

Non-existent? On the risk of missing your point if that's what you meant,
but this card has the most intrusive flavor-explaining flavor text I've seen so far.
And colorless Karn getting shown most prominently behind Sisay makes this work even better.

However, the idea gets kind of ridiculous when you counter a WUBRG like Progenitus with it:

"Calm down everyone; it's nothing we haven't seen before." —Sisay
"LIKE HELL WE HAVE!" —Gerrard, Tarngarth and Karn
"...I'll get my toy." —Squee


On a sidenote, this is the very idea used to justify the functionality of Fear's descendant, Intimidate.

Guys, um, I hate to break it to you, but they do not print cards that turn all your cards into CMC 2 in Standard.

I think it would be difficult to get an Elvish Piper reprint in the Core Set actually. Mythic Rares and Planeswalkers just in general increase the power Creatures have to be at for Standard to be OK (If the Creatures didn't wreck people, the Planeswalker Deck would flat out replace the card type).


I'm trying to imagine any scenario in which Wizards would let you play with 20 Lands, 30 multicolored cards ranging in mana costs from 4 to 8, and a spell suite designed to force this card onto the battlefield ASAP. No, I don't think so. This card would have make Diabolic Tutor playable in Standard. It would have been awkward to make the deck fully work, but it would have been probably way WAY more powerful than Maze's End.


Just.....no people. It's too much like Tinker Think about it in those terms. XD

26743: Fungal Shambler.author: achilleselbow
26743: Fungal Shambler.text_parsed:
Well, he costs 7 mana and if he doesn't get removed immediately he'll probably die to a 4/4 the first time he attacks. On the other hand, you're almost guaranteed to get some trample damage through, which will trigger the ability. So you'll get to remove a mid-size creature, draw a card, and make your opponent discard one. Not the worst use of 7 mana, but not the best either.

Also, has anyone noticed that they messed up on the mana cost symbols? If you look at any other multicolored card, they put the color symbols in clockwise order, starting from white, so green should always be last.

26743: Fungal Shambler.author: majinara
26743: Fungal Shambler.text_parsed:
Fun with Quicksilver Dagger. Tap him at the end of the opponents draw step: deal 1 damage, draw two cards, opponent discards a card. :)

Giving him double strike is pretty neat too. Since it kills most blockers with int he first strike combat damage step, the lower toughness ain't such a drawback then. Thanks to the trample, the damaeg in the regular combat step won't be wasted, even if the shambler gets blocked. And if it deals more damage then necessary, you draw two cards and make your opponent discard two cards.

26756: Razorfin Hunter.author: Equinox523
26756: Razorfin Hunter.text_parsed:
Part of an interesting cycle of 2-mana enemy color gold common creatures in Apocalypse:

Gaea's Skyfolk - (Elf Merfolk)
Goblin Legionnaire - (Goblin Soldier)
Llanowar Dead - (Zombie Elf)
Putrid Warrior - (Zombie Soldier - later Warrior was added)
Razorfin Hunter - (Merfolk Goblin)

Invasion, the first expansion in the block, had a cycle of 2-mana friendly color gold common creatures, all of which had protection from their shared enemy color:

Galina's Knight - (Merfolk Knight)
Llanowar Knight - (Elf Knight)
Shivan Zombie - (Barbarian Zombie)
Vodalian Zombie - (Merfolk Zombie)
Yavimaya Barbarian - (Elf Barbarian)

As for this card itself, it's pretty good. Not only is it one of the cheapest CMC Tims in the game, but also two very relevant creature types, with a wealth of support from both colors: Crushing Pain, Sigil of Sleep, Curiosity...the list goes on. Interestingly enough, it's also the smallest creature in the cycle. I guess this might be out of respect for how good the ability can be, especially in Limited, and especially with multiple copies.
26756: Razorfin Hunter.text_posted:
Part of an interesting cycle of 2-mana enemy color gold common creatures in Apocalypse:

26757: Gaea's Skyfolk.author: Equinox523
26757: Gaea's Skyfolk.text_parsed:
Part of an interesting cycle of 2-mana enemy color gold common creatures in Apocalypse:

Gaea's Skyfolk - (Elf Merfolk)
Goblin Legionnaire - (Goblin Soldier)
Llanowar Dead - (Zombie Elf)
Putrid Warrior - (Zombie Soldier - later Warrior was added)
Razorfin Hunter - (Merfolk Goblin)

Invasion, the first expansion in the block, had a cycle of 2-mana friendly color gold common creatures, all of which had protection from their shared enemy color:

Galina's Knight - (Merfolk Knight)
Llanowar Knight - (Elf Knight)
Shivan Zombie - (Barbarian Zombie)
Vodalian Zombie - (Merfolk Zombie)
Yavimaya Barbarian - (Elf Barbarian)

As for this card itself, it's not bad. It can block flyers unlike Jhessian Infiltrator , has two extremely relevant creature types, and even helps these often-grounded tribes block flyers. A very playable common.

26758: Putrid Warrior.author: Equinox523
26758: Putrid Warrior.text_parsed:
Part of an interesting cycle of 2-mana enemy color gold common creatures in Apocalypse:

Gaea's Skyfolk - (Elf Merfolk)
Goblin Legionnaire - (Goblin Soldier)
Llanowar Dead - (Zombie Elf)
Putrid Warrior - (Zombie Soldier - later Warrior was added)
Razorfin Hunter - (Merfolk Goblin)

Invasion, the first expansion in the block, had a cycle of 2-mana friendly color gold common creatures, all of which had protection from their shared enemy color:

Galina's Knight - (Merfolk Knight)
Llanowar Knight - (Elf Knight)
Shivan Zombie - (Barbarian Zombie)
Vodalian Zombie - (Merfolk Zombie)
Yavimaya Barbarian - (Elf Barbarian)

As for this card itself, it's interesting in that you can choose if you want to push through one extra point of life loss, perhaps hitting for 3 unblocked, or get a point of life back, effectively making him hit for 1 that turn. However, you MUST do this every time he does damage, including when he's blocked, so more often than not you'll be able to get a point of life loss out even if he is blocked - so as long as you get off one attack, you are basically guaranteed one point of life loss. An interesting creature, but there are many better, more reliable creatures. It does however, have several relevant creature types - the addition of Warrior means he can now wield Obsidian Battle-Axe too. He can also come into play off of Preeminent Captain attacks. As with all black/white creatures, a good target for Edge of the Divinity. An interesting card with a unique ability that makes you think a little more than most commons, and with such a unique set of creature types.

By the way, if you're a fan of black/white common lifegain off of combat damage, you might like Mourning Thrull as well.

Before "Invasion" block, people would have never imagined that one day zombie decks could be multi-colored.. Now, green is the most popular second color for zombie decks because of Putrid Leech (which is probably the better two-drop) + Strength Of Night + certain control cards! :)

Yeah, this should definitely have the druid types, there are even bears that produce mana and they have the creature type: "Bear Druid".. We should probably compare this card with Werebear for another reason, the bear is first a 1/1 and then later a 4/4 creature while this card is a 2/2 creature.. And yeah, both cards show the moon and can accelerate into a third-turn Keening Banshee, which shows the moon, too! :)

26760: Goblin Legionnaire.author: Equinox523
26760: Goblin Legionnaire.text_parsed:
Part of an interesting cycle of 2-mana enemy color gold common creatures in Apocalypse:

Gaea's Skyfolk - (Elf Merfolk)
Goblin Legionnaire - (Goblin Soldier)
Llanowar Dead - (Zombie Elf)
Putrid Warrior - (Zombie Soldier - later Warrior was added)
Razorfin Hunter - (Merfolk Goblin)

Invasion, the first expansion in the block, had a cycle of 2-mana friendly color gold common creatures, all of which had protection from their shared enemy color:

Galina's Knight - (Merfolk Knight)
Llanowar Knight - (Elf Knight)
Shivan Zombie - (Barbarian Zombie)
Vodalian Zombie - (Merfolk Zombie)
Yavimaya Barbarian - (Elf Barbarian)

As for this card itself, it is highly playable and has two of the most supported creature types in Boros colors, which have enjoyed their fair share of success. The fact that he can blow himself up to Shock you is relevant if you get into awkward situations where attacking into the enemy is ill-advised (for example, if the opponent's blockers have lifelink, or you can't break through a line of tokens and need that damage desperately). The second ability, while significantly less aggressive, can help keep you alive as well.

That said, though, this was much better pre-M10, when you could attack or block, and with damage on the stack, use one of the abilities. This made for some odd situations where you had your cake, and ate it too. Still a great card though, and I would have been really happy to see it reprinted with a Boros watermark.

26783: Standard Bearer.author: LordRandomness
26783: Standard Bearer.text_parsed:
Fun with Amoeboid Changeling x2. You can simply strip her of her Flagbearer status and bestow it upon an opposing creature, forcing them to target that if they want to play anything!

As an additional bonus, unlike Spellskite she soaks up abilities too, and prevents your opponent from using any buff spells! Apparently she's a target for the enemy's buffs too.

Finally, self-bounce options like Whitemane Lion are effective since she has a low cost to re-cast. Deadeye Navigator is sure to annoy the hell out of everyone, too.

However, Tainted Peak + Tainted Field can help you! :) Also, why do people here compare this card with other cards that ~can't~ destroy creatures? Prison Term doesn't remove Soul Warden.. As we're in red/white/black colors, I'd rather compare this card with Terminate! :)

26797: Jilt.author: jsttu
26797: Jilt.text_parsed:
expensive unsummon with options. not bad. can certainly achieve card advantage.

edit: You're right about the tempo, although that in itself is a form of card advantage, as you spend one card to remove 2, no matter how temporary, and they must spend the mana again to play the card. You play one spell to take care of two and cause them to waste a turn to boot. No matter what you want to call it, i like it.

As for their personality, you do realize that their individual personalities were very well developed in the books, right? just because flavor text doesn't give the most information doesn't mean it isn't there.

And FYI: in response to you saying they are killing each other, that isn't Hanna, it is Yawgmoth disguised as her. Thus the flavortext.

edit: You're right about the tempo, although that in itself is a form of card advantage, as you spend one card to remove 2, no matter how temporary, and they must spend the mana again to play the card. You play one spell to take care of two and cause them to waste a turn to boot. No matter what you want to call it, i like it.

As for their personality, you do realize that their individual personalities were [u]very[/u] well developed in the books, right? just because flavor text doesn't give the most information doesn't mean it isn't there.

And FYI: in response to you saying they are killing each other, that isn't Hanna, it is Yawgmoth disguised as her. Thus the flavortext.

26805: Tundra Kavu.author: longwinded
26805: Tundra Kavu.text_parsed:
It took me way, way, too long to figure this out that Tundra Kavu, Slimy Kavu, and Kavu Recluse were supposed to be Domain enablers. Since all of those are red, there's no mountain-making Kavu. And, given that Kavu Scout is the only kavu with a Domain ability, I don't think it's going to be real useful in a tribal deck.

I guess they decided white and blue were the least likely colors to fit into a Kavu deck, so they put both island- and plains-making on this guy. I'm not sure that's the best way to pack all four of these abilities onto a few Kavu, but I do agree that there's not enough room in a set for four of essentially the same thing. I'm not entirely sure I would have bothered with three.

"Any clues to why his Bloodfire bros also damage flying creatures?"

@garbagegatherer because the bigger the bloodfire creature gets, not only the damage it deals is increased, but also area of effect: Bloodfire Colossus, unlike Bloodfire Kavu, also affects players.

The area of effect change might have been chosen because each of those creatures from this vertical cycle mimic a familiar burn spell when you sacrifice them:
The dwarf creates a Tremor, the kavu a Pyroclasm and the colossus an Inferno.
(As additional feature, each of those burn spells also happens to match the rarity of the respective creature.)

26810: Dwarven Landslide.author: marmaris74
26810: Dwarven Landslide.text_parsed:
Everyone here is really underestimating this card's potential. You don't have to cast it for {5}{R}{R}. At worst, this card is just a stone rain for {1} more, so you can always play stone rain on t3 and this on t4. However, if you're playing a dedicated land destruction deck, the kicker can come in handy. Because you can't destroy any lands prior to t3, it's hard to stop your opponent from getting a few lands out. Using this card, you can hit two lands with one card in one turn, which will help you get down your opponent's land count (and since ~50% of your deck is cheap stone rain variants, it's unlikely that you'd need your 7th land anyway).
Anyway, if you're trying to make a mono-red land destruction deck, the only cards there are that always destroy a land, with no drawback to you, and that cost <5 are:
Avalanche Riders // Demolish
Earth Rift // Flowstone Flood
Goblin Settler // Lay Waste
Melt Terrain // Molten Rain
Pain//Suffering // Pillage
Poison the Well // Roiling Terrain
Seismic Spike // Stone Rain
Sunder from Within // Tectonic Rift
I don't see how many of these cards are rated better than Dwarven Landslide.

26810: Dwarven Landslide.text_posted:
Everyone here is really underestimating this card's potential. You don't have to cast it for {5}{R}{R}. At worst, this card is just a [autocard]stone rain[/autocard] for {1} more, so you can always play [autocard]stone rain[/autocard] on t3 and this on t4. However, if you're playing a dedicated land destruction deck, the kicker can come in handy. Because you can't destroy any lands prior to t3, it's hard to stop your opponent from getting a few lands out. Using this card, you can hit two lands with one card in one turn, which will help you get down your opponent's land count (and since ~50% of your deck is cheap [autocard]stone rain[/autocard] variants, it's unlikely that you'd need your 7th land anyway). 
Anyway, if you're trying to make a mono-red land destruction deck, the only cards there are that always destroy a land, with no drawback to you, and that cost <5 are:
[autocard]Avalanche Riders[/autocard]  //  [autocard]Demolish[/autocard]
[autocard]Earth Rift[/autocard]  //  [autocard]Flowstone Flood[/autocard]
[autocard]Goblin Settler[/autocard]  //  [autocard]Lay Waste[/autocard]
[autocard]Melt Terrain[/autocard]  //  [autocard]Molten Rain[/autocard]
[autocard multiverseid="259281"]Pain//Suffering[/autocard]  //  [autocard]Pillage[/autocard]
[autocard]Poison the Well[/autocard]  //  [autocard]Roiling Terrain[/autocard]
[autocard]Seismic Spike[/autocard]  //  [autocard]Stone Rain[/autocard]
[autocard]Sunder from Within[/autocard]  //  [autocard]Tectonic Rift[/autocard]
I don't see how many of these cards are rated better than [autocard]Dwarven Landslide[/autocard].
It's no stone rain, but it's still rated far too low.

26822: Soul Link.author: majinara
26822: Soul Link.text_parsed:
@ liir007 Top 10 most popular on the gatherer auras you mean. :) They are not the top 10 best auras. I'd put stuff like necromancy, griffin guide or confiscate (just as examples) in my decks 10 times over spirit link or soul link.

Regarding soul link: it's ok if you have some kind of combo with it (ie a creature that deals tons of damage to everything including itself). However, the "receives damage" part is often rather irrelevant, since when that creature receives damage it's likely to die. And when a creature of yours dies on which you placed an aura, then you're in trouble anyway. :)

2.5/5

26822: Soul Link.author: CORRBentOrgy
26822: Soul Link.text_parsed:
I sense majinara has lost to too many lifegain decks. Shutting down a creature is never a bad thing; ever. Neither is constantly thwarting you opponent's ability to kill you, over, and over, and over. The only things that ruin lifegain are poison counters and the fact that sometimes, you can't establish a lead fast enough. Any deck running things like this that are worth anything are dedicated to their theme, and hence can survive long enough to gain momentum.

End of story.

26831: Squee's Revenge.author: s0phocles
26831: Squee's Revenge.text_parsed:
Terrible card.

Consider the the possibilities:
1 flip = 50% chance of drawing 2 cards, an average of 1 card drawn.
2 flips = 25% chance of drawing 4 cards, an average of 1 card drawn.
3 flips = 12.5% chance of drawing 6 cards, an average of 0.75 cards drawn.
4 flips = 6.25% chance of drawing 8 cards, an average of 0.5 cards drawn.
It gets progressively worse from there.

The best option mathematically gives you an average of 1 card for a card that costs 3 mana or different colors. Definitely not worth it.

26831: Squee's Revenge.author: stevebugge
26831: Squee's Revenge.text_parsed:
s0phocles stats are correct, the way this works is that you have to win every flip.
So if you pick just 1 flip your odds are 1 in 2 of getting the right call, assuming that it's a truly even chance.
If you pick two filps the probability get expoentially worse, 1 in 2 chance twice,
say you pick Heads, Heads that's just on possible permutation
You could get Heads Heads, Heads Tails, Tails Heads, or Tails, Tails.

Going to 3 flips it gets worse as there are 8 possible permutaitons, your chances of it working are 1 in 2^X where X is the total number of flips. If you want to use this card you need a way to mdify the odds (like Krark's Thumb)

Sophocles is right.

Think about it this way.

Each time, you have half the chance you did last time of draw how ever many cards you picked.

The number of cards drawn is 2x, right? (twice the number of flips you pick)

And the chance of you actually drawing is .5^x? So 2x(.5^x) will go straight down, since the exponential part starts making a bigger and bigger difference. And since the difference is down, it will go down, faster at first, then slower, and eventually even out at .0000000000000000001. That's not drawing very many cards, now is it?

So yeah, in summary, it's pretty horrible. Try divination, or something.

26848: Dead Ringers.author: Leshrac_Nightwalker
26848: Dead Ringers.text_parsed:
I remember being at the Apocalypse prerelease... we were cracking open our packs, and the head judge at the event stepped up to the mic to remind us of the usual deckbuilding rules and tournament structures. Then, in a twist from the norm, he added that he wanted to mention a rules clarification on one card... Dead Ringers.

When I had first read the card, I thought "Okay, the wording is a bit awkward but I think I understand what this does". Listening to the head judge at this event try to clarify it, though, made a lot of us look around at one another in confusion... what was so confusing about this? Did we all miss something? Had we actually misunderstood it to begin with?

There are a lot of Magic cards that use the word "unless", but the vast majority of them have that word because they offer a player a "choice" of sorts. Counter a spell unless they pay ... discard 2 cards unless you discard an artifact... this is the only case I can think of where the word "unless" doesn't actually offer a choice at all. It's just a cleaner template than saying "Destroy two target nonblack, identically-coloured creatures. They can't be regenerated."

If you are familiar with the expression "a dead ringer" (it means an exact duplicate), then you've got a better shot at interpreting this card correctly upon first reading it. You've also got the option to chuckle knowingly about the pun! (though to speak technically, the card should be named "Dead Dead Ringers"!)

When I had first read the card, I thought "Okay, the wording is a bit awkward but I think I understand what this does". 26854: Helionaut.text_parsed:
@ Spe11caster

It gives you mana, not lands. Lands give you mana, they are not mana themselves. Mana has no card associated with it. Don't feel bad for the mistake though, I see A LOT of beginning players make this mistake. Why? Because they took the wording off of the basic lands and replaced it with just the symbol. When a new player looks at a basic land, they see a {R} and think that {R} is what 'Mountain' means. So when they see {R} on nonland sources, they think it lets them search for a Mountain. Not so. Spe11caster, you're not alone! I can't even count the times I've had to explain this, right up with the fact that lands are colorless.

Wizards, please bring back the {T}!

27137: Divine Light.author: asmallcat
27137: Divine Light.text_parsed:
It's not supposed to be a combat trick per se, and it's actually an interesting effect for one. Play this then earthquake. Play this then pyroclasm. Play this then wildfire. It can make cards that are supposed to effect everyone equally ridiculously one-sided.

Finally, you can play it before you swing to force bad blocks out of your opponent. Very strong with high power low toughness cards, or against a 1st strike or deathtouch creature.

Certainly not a 5-star card, but interesting enough to be 3 stars.

27156: Tahngarth's Glare.author: DrJack
27156: Tahngarth's Glare.text_parsed:
I consider this to be the worst card ever printed. (In terms of power and user-friendliness, not art necessarily). We all knew it would either be a red or green card... right? So here's the breakdown: Tahngarth's Glare costs you a card just to look at your opponent's next 3 cards, while allowing your opponent to do the same and put you in a worse position. Your opponent doesn't lose a card and doesn't have to spend mana. This card has got to be a joke from the "Wizards". At least Natural Selection doesn't let your opponent peek at your deck. And red has had Orcish Spy from eons ago which lets you look at the top 3 cards of ANY player's library, every single turn, and your opponent doesn't get that advantage.

@ DoragonShinzui - First, it doesn't matter if a color "never gets those effects". There is no excuse to make extremely weak cards like these. Second, take a look at the older Orcish Spy. That's when they got this effect for red just right. Forget about the trite, bland "Color Pie". All 5 colors used to be much more entertaining before they screwed it all up.

27158: Reef Shaman.author: Calver

I have a casual Blast deck (Distorting Lens/other color manipulators + (Hydro)Pyroblast/(Blue)Red Elemental Blast).
I'm considering augmenting it by comboing this card with Active Volcano and Flash Flood. It's one turn quicker than using the Lens (which I can drop and abuse on turn 3: 2 to cast and 1 to Blast), which means I can keep my opponent to 1 land if I go first and avoid the chance that he pulls his Disenchant/Naturalize for my Distorting Lens. Active/Flash can even be used in place of my Blasts to clear the board.

27160: Symbiotic Deployment.author: Tevish_Szat
27160: Symbiotic Deployment.text_parsed: Yes, this is an instant loss to Wrath of God or similar effects, so it will never see competitive play where everyone and their brother runs wrath effects. However, due to the general rarity of wraths and the expense of good ones, this card's bane is not seen so often in casual, allowing it to truly shine. A saproling swarm, or even a mass of elves, can benefit by running this and knowing when to cast it. And it's not like we're without ways to make an army vanish for a moment, then reappear(less tokens) when the danger has passed, allowing wrath insurance in richer and more competitive kitchen-table environments.

27160: Symbiotic Deployment.author: blurrymadness
27160: Symbiotic Deployment.text_parsed:
I think I nuke the board enough that I can't use this card. Nuking the board is crucial to getting through a lot of aggro decks and especially multiplayer where if you have no nukes, players get out of control too easily. I think roughly half of my decks have nukes, the other half having lots of targetted/repeatable removal.

This is a decent card, but it has to be reasonably low levels of play to be successful, even in casual, as it's too easy to screw yourself. That said, if you have cheap enchantment removal or phasing effects this could easily be averted unless your run into both nukes AND discard at the same time.

3/5

27162: Life // Death.author: GrimjawxRULES
27162: Life // Death.text_parsed:
A powerful reanimation spell and the ability to turn your lands into creatures for a mass attack in one, nifty little package.
Also, this doesn't combo very well with Overrun: Remember that casting Life and Overrun in the same turn requires 6 mana, meaning that 6 of your would-be manlands are going to be tapped by the time your combat phase starts.

If you really want to abuse Life, you should use it in a deck based around Earth Surge and manlands.

27162: Life // Death.author: blurrymadness
27162: Life // Death.text_parsed:
Double win condition:
-Win by swinging with weenie lands
-Win by reanimating fat

Works great for it's versatility. You may still choose Reanimate over it for it's ability to target opponent's graveyards; saving you $140 while allowing you play tarmogoyf :)

Each of the two cards is more versatile in it's own way. I'll be trying both, but I feel that it's much harder to deal with an instant swing of 8-10 land damage than it is to deal with a reanimated goyf. One is hastey and not vulnerable to main-deck hate most of the time; and it works with almost any kind of hate the opponent can reasonably expect to have. You can even mid-game swing for 5-ish. Consider Gaea's Anthem in casual to make those lands hit hard.

27162: Life // Death.author: DarthParallax
27162: Life // Death.text_parsed:
This card is full of Irony, since the Trampling 1/1s will cause a player to die! ^_^

(you *DID* give them Trample, right? o_O ARE YOU A GREEN PLANESWALKER OR NOT?)

I love this card-- although it's cheaply costed enough to be a win-condition on either half, it's also a card that's easy to play around in a number of ways:

Having a good Wall creature.

Having a multi-blocker creature.

Having a creature that *must* be multiblocked.

Having a Bigger creature.

Are ALL ways to answer it from the other side of the table, and that's just in non-meta Magic (which is not EXACTLY "Unstrategic" Magic, since I say Tactics are kind of like Strategy), where you don't consider deliberate focused bullet-answers like Counterspell, Terror, Wrath effects, or Lightning Bolt and Drain Life before the opponent can kill you.


It's both consummately fair and yet undeniably powerful! A-TRIPLE-plus Design and Development :)


Gatherer thinks so too: I looked up "Invasion Block, in order of Community Rating", and this is sitting pretty next to Phyrexian Arena, far ahead of anything like the MULTICOLORED DRAGON cycle, things with KICKER, or you know, VINDICATE.

27169: Guided Passage.author: Scyll
27169: Guided Passage.text_parsed: In a combo deck, you're bound to have cards with redundant effects to make sure not to draw a blank. In that case, Guided Passage makes it so you'll have cards you want, regardless of the game state. I prefer it to other "draw three" spells in that you're sure to not hit three lands or two copies of the same card. Worldly Tutor is great, yes, but in the end you only get one card, then have to wait to draw said card, whereas this allows you more control on what you'll get (by using redundant creatures, for example) and nets you two more cards in hand to boot.

27169: Guided Passage.author: majinara
27169: Guided Passage.text_parsed:
Uses it has:
a) it draws 3 cards for 3 mana, among them some land and nonlands which is nice
b) in a multiplayer FFA game, if player A is about to win, play guided passage targeting player B. Player B will give you the cards needed to stop player
c) in a multiplayer game, if you are the dominating player, play this card targeting an opponent and say "give me good cards OR ELSE!!"
d) Have a deck with many 4-ofs. Have guided passage as only non-land non-creature card, and each guided passage will force your opponent to give you another guided passage, which you can then play to get another and another. Then just find a way to shuffle your library and repeat. That way you get tons of lands and creatures.
e) win condition. Play this card, force your opponent to look at your deck, and he will concede if your deck is good enough. :P

27169: Guided Passage.author: cats_and_me
27169: Guided Passage.text_parsed:
Oh my god, I have seen decks with over 2000 cards with Invincible Hymn as centerpiece.. If you're playing in a tournament, there's a restiction on your maximum deck size, you have to be able to shuffle it without any help: What could be the number of cards in your deck, 200 or 300 or 400? And how much time would your opponent have to choose the cards?

Anyway, one of the most popular red/blue/green archetypes creates card-advantage with Ceta Sanctuary and other cards and then discards them to enchantments like Stormbind + Meteor Storm that also happen to activate Ceta Sanctuary, and this card would probably fit into there, if there weren't better options! :)

27169: Guided Passage.author: MacBizzle
27169: Guided Passage.text_parsed:
Mr. leomistico is not a Johnny.

This tutors for 3 ENTIRELY separate cards. Sure, they're of an opponent's choice, but at least it's not like "i give u 2 islinds and forrest lol". All you need to do is ensure that all the creatures in your deck can function with the combo (like bringing an instant or sorcery out of the graveyard, like Mnemonic Wall, Anarchist, Scrivener, Izzet Chonarch), non-creature non-land cards can work with them (Rite of Replication (late game when you have a graveyard) or a Followed Footsteps (early game) on one of said creatures), and THEN another land for three mana?! Not to mention, if you run four of these in an Intet deck, everyone's going to be giving you cheap stuff, as opposed to that Darksteel Colossus or whatever the hell you want to play for free with Intet the Dreamer anyways.

27169: Guided Passage.author: scumbling1
27169: Guided Passage.text_parsed:
"I find a little funny how some cards that give an opponent choises (Gifts Ungiven, Intuition, this card...) are valued high, but other cards (one for all: Dash Hopes) are valued very low... I think that maybe it's all in the execution..."

Cards like Inuition and Gifts Ungiven can be used to force the opponent into giving you a desired result. With Intuition, just grab three of the same card and you have a blue Demonic Tutor. There are ways to get precisely what you want with Gifts Ungiven as well (Regrowth,Recoup, Yawgmoth's Will, ect). There is little choice for your opponent if you play the cards well. The same can't be said for Dash Hopes and it's kind. These cards give the opponent complete control over what happens, unless their life total is so low that they can't pay. There are no such conditions to be met to get Intuition and Gifts Ungiven to produce the desired effect.

27169: Guided Passage.author: Salient
27169: Guided Passage.text_parsed:
It's easy to lose sight of this amidst all the choosing, but: this is a draw three spell. Three cards for three mana is great. Knowing what sorts of cards you're going to get is extra great.

It's playable in Legacy. In fact, for a while, the "no rug" Natural Order decks were using a couple of these, forcing the opponent to wonder, "Soooo, do I give my opponent a Vendillion Clique they could cast or pitch to Force of Will, or a green creature they can sacrifice for Natural Order?"

You didn't see more than one or two per deck, and this show up in even the majority of no rug decks, because nailing a three-color casting cost is awfully hard in a format with Wasteland. But it's still a great card; in some cases it's superior to Standstill.

27178: Dega Sanctuary.author: DarthParallax
27178: Dega Sanctuary.text_parsed:
darkfury seems to be trying to make what might be a good point, but unclearly-

Tell me, how many of you are here because Kaalia is a WBR creature, and you are looking for cards for Commander? I do not know all the rules about Color Identiy and hybrid, though, so darkfury might be wrong even for Commander.

Besides that, a deck other than mono-white would have a very difficult time making Divinity of Pride and Nobilis of War work. they are strong cards, so I assume you'd like to draw them. Let's say you have 4 of each- that's 8 cards out of 60, which is a good percentage of your deck. Even though Dual Lands can make it a lot easier, I wouldn't be surprised to see the decklist that includes 4x Nobilis and 4x Divinity looking very close to mono-white.

It would probably even run Armored Ascension (which you might remember came from the same 4-part block as those creatures, so it would a card you'd be quick to think of if you were already considering the Spirit Avatars)

While it is certainly legal to put those cards in a non-mono white deck, it would be so difficult to build compared to how simple an All White deck version would be, that I think darkfury's post deserves a couple more stars. at least 3.

27179: Raka Sanctuary.author: SquareHippy
27179: Raka Sanctuary.text_parsed:
Nagoragama: So gaining 4 life a turn off Dega Sanctuary wins you the game, but killing their creatures does not?

Ratrase: Raka Sanctuary does 1 damage to target creature. Says that it deals damage right there on the card. Furthermore, protection prevents damage, so even if it didn't target, Azorius First-Wing would still survive.

Based on the comments here, this seems like a fairly underrated card in a rather mediocre cycle. Certainly, the cards are interesting, but that's mainly due to the requirements and the semi-efficiency of the otherwise stock-standard effects. This could certainly be a component, alongside many of the UW cards mentioned on this page, in a RWU control deck, with several enchantments that ping off your opponent's creatures. Sadly, the only other card I could suggest would be Magmatic Core. But if you toss in some Enlightened Tutors and Idyllic Tutor, this deck could work in Casual. Seems like enchantments that uncontrollably attack creatures is some unexplored design space for R&D to look at. I'd bet on an Ajani's Mantra-esque card in a Core Set at some point.

27187: Prophetic Bolt.author: The_Sturm
27187: Prophetic Bolt.text_parsed: I'd rather play a Bituminous Blast.

27187: Prophetic Bolt.author: Daijin26
27187: Prophetic Bolt.text_parsed:
@the sturm.

Bituminous Blast isn't as good: you can only target creatures for the 4 damage, so it's not as flexible in its targeting. Also, Cascade forces you to either play or lose to exile the first card that is revealed that has a lower converted cost than the Bituminous Blast; you don't get to save it in your hand for later. Furthermore, the card you get to play for free may not be a card you want, but Cascade gives you no say in what card you get to play, so again, lack of flexibility in the card aspect as well as damage. And to me, playing the card for free doesn't offset that fact that I may be forced to play a card that won't help me in the given situation when Cascade goes off; I've never been a fan of Cascade because of this.

Prophetic Bolt can deal the 4 damage to a player or creature and it doesn't care about the cost of a card as you look at in the top four of your deck, you get to choose any one of the 4 cards to put in your hand. Furthermore, you're not forced to play the card you choose immediately; you put it in your hand and can thus keep it for later to use at a better time.

And all that for the same converted cost of 5 and both are instants. So all around, Prophetic Bolt is better than Bituminous Blast.

27231: Last Stand.author: ScissorsLizard
27231: Last Stand.text_parsed:
Esprel's right, actually. If you use this card the way it was printed to be used (with one or two of each land type) it's actually pretty underwhelming. Maybe magic's just come a long way since Apocalypse, but nowadays I expect a lot more when I pay {W}{U}{B}{R}{G}.

Ironically, a modern enchantment, Prismatic Omen, raised this card up to the force to be reckoned with that its name and cost suggests it should be. With Prismatic Omen in play, by the time you can play Last Stand you will have at least +10 life, target player loses 10 life, 5 damage to target creature, 5 1/1 saprolings in play, and draw/discard 5 cards.

That'll pretty much give you the game in most cases. If the 10 life loss doesn't end the game outright, the saprolings and life gain should keep you alive long enough to use the second one (or another bomb) you probably just drew.

27583: Suffocating Blast.author: DoctorKenneth
27583: Suffocating Blast.text_parsed:
@TheFrostReaper:
I would rather play Baneslayer Angel over Serra Angel. I would rather play Thoughtsieze over Duress. Etcetera, etcetera. Format defining staple cards are better than their predecesors. Who knew?

Compare Cryptic Command to nearly any other four-mana counterspell. It wins. That does not make everything that has come before it inhertly bad. This is a good card, especially for the burn/counter strategy of blue-red.

Damaging players is nice, but for a control strategy (which blue-red clearly is. It's the instant/sorcery combination), dealing with opposing creatures to stabilize the board is the kind of thing you want to do, not beat your foe down. That comes later.

And it's not overcosted at all, actually, even by moden standards. Cancel is 1UU. Lightning bolt is R. There we have it. (Or, if you'd rather, Incinerate for 1R and Counterspell for UU). The limiting factor on the Bolt (unable to hit players) is the cost you pay for the card advantage (combining it into one card instead of getting the same effect for two cards).

27583: Suffocating Blast.author: Blackworm_Bloodworm
27583: Suffocating Blast.text_parsed:
This card could very easily cost for a couple of reasons:
If you consider Counterspell to be the baseline power level for counterspells, you're paying that plus an extra for a situational Lightning Bolt (more like a reverse Lava Spike). And Counterspell is a common.

Even if you consider Cancel to be baseline power, it's still a common; this is rare. You're replacing a colorless mana symbol for a colored one, and that's enough to give it another effect, even if it weren't rare. Compare Negate with Countersquall to see what I mean.

 If you consider [autocard]Counterspell[/autocard] to be the baseline power level for counterspells, you're paying that plus an extra [R] for a situational [autocard]Lightning Bolt[/autocard] (more like a reverse [autocard]Lava Spike[/autocard]). And Counterspell is a common.

Even if you consider [autocard]Cancel[/autocard] to be baseline power, it's still a common; this is rare. 27591: Last Caress.author: Ameisenmeister
27591: Last Caress.text_parsed:
XTwistedsoulX, I hope you are joking. A tattoo of a magic card is the most nerdy thing I can imagine...

EDIT: Since I posted this comment in year 2010 I've gotten far more into the game now (2013) and I can say that Magic has become a very important part of my life too. I even have one wall of my flat decorated with a collage of cards and it looks great.
The time and your comment, XTwistedsoulX, made me think about what I could do and what I do and what the reasons are I do not show more about myself and what I like. In fact, the idea of a magic-wall came to me much earlier but I was afraid that when some non-magic-friends visit me they'll make fun of me. I guess you were very right by saying that if people don't like it, you'll probally won't mesh well with them. It is as weird to get yourself sorrounded (or partly covered) with magic as it is to collect soccer-stickers or take pictures of particular cars which both are big things among Germans of every age.
So yeah, I apologize for my comment to you and thank you for your illuminative and notably not-insulting comment. Thanks & Sorry!

27602: False Dawn.author: Mode
27602: False Dawn.text_parsed:
@psychokid121: Except that Celestial Dawn costs more, not a cantrip, an Enchantment, turns everything in your deck white and only allows you to use non-white mana as colorless mana.
You might argue that "Celestial Dawn is a better realization of the concept of this effect", but just saying it's a better card is dumb, these two are totally different cards.
27602: False Dawn.text_posted:
@psychokid121: Except that [autocard]Celestial Dawn[/autocard] costs [W] more, not a cantrip, an Enchantment, turns everything in your deck white and only allows you to use non-white mana as colorless mana.
You might argue that "[i]Celestial Dawn is a better realization of the concept of this effect[/i]", but just saying it's a better card is dumb, these two are totally different cards.

27602: False Dawn.author: WhereDidItGo

27602: False Dawn.text_posted: The errata actually makes sense when you consider that the lands of the time all spelled out "{T}: Add (color) to your mana pool", which this card would then turn into "{T}: Add {W} to your mana pool".

27659: Tidal Courier.author: Salient
27659: Tidal Courier.text_parsed:
Interesting card advantage option for Merfolk, but, uh, blue doesn't lack for card advantage options (Silvergill Adept especially), and 4cc is actually quite tough for Legacy Merfolk because they exploit Wasteland and Mutavault so much (at least 3cc stuff can be churned out with Aether Vial; bumping the Vial to 4cc is dooming it to uselessness next turn).

Maybe if Merfolk gets up to a reliable 20 Lord low-counters-count model, a couple of these could slip in alongside the Adepts. I think I'd still be pitching it to Force of Will all the time, though.

Dark Confidant is a 2/1 creature with one less skull in the top right corner, so it can and often does get additional attacks through. Furthermore, in Legacy, Brainstorm and Sensei's Divining Top can oftentimes eliminate Bob's down-side.

As has been said, Arena is killer in a slow-rolling control deck, but Confidant is even better in a tight-running mid-range deck like Jund.

27663: Phyrexian Arena.author: DarthParallax
27663: Phyrexian Arena.text_parsed:
In the Underworld Dreams.DEC that likes to run The Rack, Black Vise, et. al., and in fact is perfectly happy to leave almost its entire mana production at T1 Swamp -> Sol Ring, T2 Dark Ritual -> Dreams, and then be completely done making mana?

I can see how I wouldn't want to play Phyrexian Arena in that deck. Or, EVEN, Necropotence. Necropotence in that deck would be something like taking a heavy repeating nuclear cannon to a Western shootout at Sundown. I mean, I just don't need it because the cards I'm going to pick for a Discard Grief Deck will be fine and reliable without The Skull, like the dusty pair of pistols you shoot someone with in a proper Duel.

However, this still proves that you just used the phrase "Strictly" completely improperly, like most people do. -.-

Underworld Dreams: Legends Good for Mill Decks

Necropotence: Ice Age Good for Control or Combo Decks, varying ranges of Stupid

Yawgmoth's Bargain: Urza's Destiny Good for Stupid Combo Decks, Only for Stupid Combo Decks

Phyrexian Arena: Apocalypse Good for anything from replacing Howling Mine or Sign in Blood to a lot more sinister things.

Dark Confidant: Ravnica, City of Guilds Good for Aggressive Mid-range where every card is pretty much both a Spell and a Creature. Has 2 more power than P.A., does about 10 more damage.

Bloodgift Demon: Innistrad: Good for when ......Good for....Good when Griselbrand gets banned in EDH and you don't have the others :P He's Fun :)

These cards are incredibly similar to each other, but they belong in different decks. Griselbrand belongs in exactly the decks Yawgmoth's Bargain does, and STRICTLY *is* appropriate there. It's not appropriate to compare the others to, because mana cost, it turns out, really dictates the direction, focus, wants/needs of the decks that much. You COULD Dark Ritual into most of these, but you wouldn't.
Actually, I don't know anyone that would Dark Ritual into Bob, when casting him T2 is usually a perfectly Awesome Play anyway and that Dark Ritual can be used to do better things.

One of the reasons goblins were so good back in the day is because of this guy. Most aggro decks run into trouble if they run out of cards and the enemy is gaining control or parity--goblins could just refill their hands and provide a cheap beating stick (with goblin warchief, this guy only costs 3).

Combo potential with goblin recruiter notwithstanding. The recruiter-ringleader-food chain deck was crazy.

27666: Sylvan Messenger.author: fissionessence
27666: Sylvan Messenger.text_parsed:
Andrew's Occasional Random Card of the Day #3 - 6/29/2011 - Sylvan Messenger

With such a big war going on in their setting, Invasion block's card names often surprise me. It's full of acolytes, disciples, apprentices, emissaries, and apparently messengers. Regardless, though, this card is funny in a different way; it's a tribal card in a block about multicolor. A quick search shows me only three Elves in Apocalypse, including this one, while there are sixteen in the Invasion block. One of those is Elvish Champion, though, so it's hard to argue there. Still, Sylvan Messenger feels a little out of place. It's even too early to be a 'plant' for Onslaught, since Odyssey block was a buffer between the two in terms of the Standard format.

I'm not an Elf-deck-type, so I could be off, but I've never even really seen this card in decks of its genre, apart from its inclusion in the Elves vs Goblins Duel Deck. Contrariwise, its counterpart Goblin Ringleader gets sleeved up all the time. The ringleader says, "Jump off a cliff," everyone follows, but when the butchy elf girl mounts a kavu and unleashes her battle shout, she gets kept in the 'old green uncommons' stack.

27669: Penumbra Wurm.author: kiseki
27669: Penumbra Wurm.text_parsed:
This was a long time ago, but it is still a solid card.
I used it with Ashnod's Altar, Juniper Order Ranger, and Twilight Shepherd to make 6/6 tramplers for each that I spent. Well I did until Mitotic Slime came out (two 2/2's for each ). Nowadays anti-wrath creatures are in every set, but they were pretty rare in 2001 when this punked Rootbreaker Wurm.
I won a lot of games with Penumbra Wurm and this gives me warm fuzzy feelings when I remember it.

27670: Whirlpool Rider.author: roguepariah
27670: Whirlpool Rider.text_parsed:
This and Trusted Advisor are the all stars in my Psychosis Crawler deck.

turn 1 drop aether vial
turn 2 play the Advisor, then the Rider to draw a new hand
turn 3 return the Rider and use the vial to flash him into play at instant speed whenever you need him

After this, your chances of hitting all your land drops and finding any combo pieces goes way up.
Also, your opponent never knows if you've run out of counters.

27671: Whirlpool Drake.author: blurrymadness
27671: Whirlpool Drake.text_parsed:
@masticore
Not really. There are certain lands you may hold onto, like those that return a land to your hand (especially if the enemy has bounce/destruction as a threat) of if you're running retrace or a similar discard mechanic, but otherwise there's no point in not dropping lands except to bluff a decent hand. Any well built deck shouldn't run into more lands than it needs/can use (you should have recurring cards, abilities that use mana, or some way of using the lands such as discard/sacrifice effects so that when you get too much mana it's not a problem.

Besides, any shot at "MasterOfEtherium" is alright in my book. He's annoying on purpose and he knows it.


To the card, you might pull an grixis combo with bazaar trader, some form of bounce and megrim/liliana's carress. Also, these effects are great on an opponent if you bounce stuff to their hand as well as it's like a semi-exile. I include the third color in the above because bazaar trader is free to use the ability of, so you don't have to cast donate the same turn, opening this up to a possible turn 4 combo without acceleration. That said, it's a 3-4 card combo that is likely to only pull about 6-10 damage. Nothing too special here.

I'd much rather just use tolarian winds, or, literally, my favorite draw engine, Windfall. Mm mm mm, love me some windfall.

Basically:
-Helps you get lands
-Helps you get rid of lands
-Helps you find your finisher
-Helps you find your control cards

Oh, and it is playable without red. If you want the red consider double lands in "monoblue" to double the effect up without having to commit to two colors. Also really good in RGB due to Green's cheap card-advantage in drawing lands (Yavimaya Elder, Cultivate, Krosan Tusker, etc..)

27672: Whirlpool Warrior.author: Equinox523
27672: Whirlpool Warrior.text_parsed: Its second ability is Winds of Change. Psychosis Crawler and Niv-Mizzet, the Firemind tricks definitely make this card shine, converting what could potentially be a pointless exercise into damage. The fact that for you can do this twice on the same turn (once for just you, and once for all players) is also insane, especially in multiplayer games. This can also break up an opponent's combo, and flush their hand if you have been using Glasses of Urza or the like to see their hand, as well as help you toss out your trash hand in favor of something better.

27674: Shield of Duty and Reason.author: tcollins
27674: Shield of Duty and Reason.text_parsed: Protection is always good, but auras are notorious for causing card disadvantage. Although protection from {G}{U} is nice, the colours that have the most creature hate are {R} and {B}. As pointed out Flickering Ward is an interesting alternative, it is more effective against decks without {G}/{U} in them, but can provide less protection in some circumstances. Also Flickering Ward has the ability to return itself to your hand, thus negating the potential card disadvantage that could result.

28009: Spiritmonger.author: Equinox523
28009: Spiritmonger.text_parsed: One of the most powerful creatures ever printed. Not only is he strong for his cost, but you can't chump block him, because he gets bigger. You can't kill him with damage, because he regenerates. You can't use a creature with protection, because he changes color and bypasses that ability. Combine this with support from Pernicious Deed, Maelstrom Pulse or Putrefy, all in-color, and you have a massive threat not many decks have ways of dealing with.

28009: Spiritmonger.author: jsttu
28009: Spiritmonger.text_parsed: This card is an amazingly good bargain. It has two very useful abilities and one situational one, all for 5 mana in a mana-ramp color. best of all, even if you never used the abilities it would still be a 6/6 for five, which by itself is above the curve. Hard to get rid of, punishes chump blocking, and hurting when it gets through all make this card a freaking monster to play against. Only white removal will reliably deal with him, making hard for other colors to cope, although blue can bounce/counter it i suppose. The sad thing is that when this guy was in standard white didn't have such nice removal as path to exile, oblivion ring or condemn. it had swords to plowshares, which was not standard legal, and that was it.
